{{infobox mineral | name = Faizievite | category = [[Silicate mineral]], [[Cyclosilicate]] | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | formula = K2Na(Ca6Na)Ti4Li6Si24O66F2 | strunz = | dana = 63.2.10.1 | system = [[Triclinic]] | class = Pinacoidal ({{overline|1}})
(same [[H-M symbol]]) | symmetry = ''P''{{overline|1}} | unit cell = a = 9.82, b = 9.82
c = 17.31 [Å], α = 99.209(2)°
β = 94.67(2)°, γ = 119.839(1)° (approximated); Z = 1 | color = Colorless | colour = | habit = tabular plates | twinning = | cleavage = None | fracture = | tenacity = Brittle | mohs = 4-4.5 | luster = Vitreous | streak = | diaphaneity = Opaque | gravity = | density = 2.83 (measured) | polish = | opticalprop = Biaxal (+) | refractive = np=1.65, nm=1.66 (approximated) | birefringence = | pleochroism = | 2V = -72o (measured), -70o (calculated, approximated) | dispersion = | extinction = | length fast/slow = | fluorescence = | absorption = | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | impurities = | alteration = | other = | references = }} '''Faizievite''' is a very rare mineral{{cite web|url=http://www.mindat.org/min-31306.html |title=Faizievite: Faizievite mineral information and data |website=Mindat.org |accessdate=2016-03-05}} with the formula K2Na(Ca6Na)Ti4Li6Si24O66F2.Agakhanov, A.A., Pautov, L.A., Uvarova, Y.A., Sokolova, E.V., Hawthorne, F.C., Karpenko, V.Y., and Gafurov, F.G., 2007. Faizievite, K2Na(Ca6Na)Ti4Li6Si24O66F2 - a new mineral species. New data on minerals 42, 5-10 This triclinic mineral is chemically related to [[baratovite]] and [[katayamalite]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mindat.org/min-512.html |title=Baratovite: Baratovite mineral information and data |website=Mindat.org |accessdate=2016-03-10}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mindat.org/min-4716.html |title=Katayamalite: Katayamalite mineral information and data |website=Mindat.org |accessdate=2016-03-10}} Faizievite is a single-locality mineral, coming from the moraine of the Darai-Pioz glacier, [[Tien Shan]] Mountains, Tajikistan. Alkaline rocks of this site are famous for containing numerous rare minerals, often enriched in boron, caesium, lithium, titanium, rare earth elements, barium, and others.{{cite web|url=http://www.mindat.org/loc-3241.html |title=Darai-Pioz Glacier (Dara-i-Pioz; Dara-Pioz), Alai Range (Alayskiy), Tien Shan Mtn, Region of Republican Subordination, Tajikistan - Mindat.org |website=Mindat.org |accessdate=2016-03-05}} ==Occurrence and association== Faizievite was detected in quartz boulders, together with [[aegirine]], [[baratovite]], [[fluorite]], [[leucosphenite]], [[pectolite]], and [[polylithionite]]. ==Notes on chemistry and structure== [[Strontium]] and trace amounts of [[rubidium]], [[barium]] and [[niobium]] are present in the structure of faizievite. One of the sodium sites is partially vacant, and fluorine may be substituted by oxygen. ==Relation to other minerals== Faizievite is related to [[beryl]] and [[osumilite]] groups of minerals. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Silicate minerals]] [[Category:Cyclosilicates]] [[Category:Lithium minerals]] [[Category:Titanium minerals]] [[Category:Potassium minerals]] [[Category:Sodium minerals]] [[Category:Calcium minerals]] [[Category:Fluorine minerals]] [[Category:Triclinic minerals]] {{mineral-stub}}

{{Infobox book | name = Gödel, Escher, Bach:
an Eternal Golden Braid | image = File:Godel, Escher, Bach (first edition).jpg | caption = Cover of the first edition | author = [[Douglas Hofstadter]] | country = United States | language = English | subjects = [[Consciousness]], [[intelligence]] | publisher = [[Basic Books]] | pub_date = 1979 | pages = 777 | isbn = 978-0-465-02656-2 | dewey = 510/.1 21 | congress = QA9.8 .H63 1999 | oclc = 40724766 | followed_by = [[I Am a Strange Loop]] }} '''''Gödel, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid''''', also known as '''''GEB''''', is a 1979 book by [[Douglas Hofstadter]]. By exploring common themes in the lives and works of logician [[Kurt Gödel]], artist [[M. C. Escher]], and composer [[Johann Sebastian Bach]], the book expounds concepts fundamental to [[mathematics]], [[symmetry]], and [[intelligence]]. Through illustration and analysis, the book discusses how, through [[self-reference]] and formal rules, systems can acquire meaning despite being made of "meaningless" elements. It also discusses what it means to communicate, how knowledge can be represented and stored, the methods and limitations of symbolic representation, and even the fundamental notion of "meaning" itself. In response to confusion over the book's theme, Hofstadter emphasized that ''Gödel, Escher, Bach'' is not about the relationships of [[mathematics and art|mathematics, art]], and [[music and mathematics|music]]—but rather about how [[Cognitive science|cognition]] [[emergence|emerges]] from hidden neurological mechanisms. One point in the book presents an analogy about how individual [[neurons]] in the [[brain]] coordinate to create a unified sense of a coherent mind by comparing it to the social organization displayed in a [[Ant colony|colony of ants]].[https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/3.11/kelly.html By Analogy: A talk with the most remarkable researcher in artificial intelligence today, Douglas Hofstadter, the author of Gödel, Escher, Bach] Wired Magazine, November 1995{{cite web|url=http://www.bizcharts.com/stoa_del_sol/conscious/conscious2.html|title=Perspective of Mind: Douglas Hofstadter|publisher=}} The tagline "a metaphorical [[fugue]] on minds and machines in the spirit of [[Lewis Carroll]]" was used by the publisher to describe the book.Hofstadter, [https://www.amazon.com/gp/reader/0465026567/ref=sib_dp_pt#reader-link cover]. ==Structure== ''Gödel, Escher, Bach'' takes the form of interweaving narratives. The main chapters alternate with dialogues between imaginary characters, usually [[Achilles and the tortoise]], first used by [[Zeno of Elea]] and later by [[Lewis Carroll]] in "[[What the Tortoise Said to Achilles]]". These origins are related in the first two dialogues, and later ones introduce new characters such as the Crab. These narratives frequently dip into [[self-reference]] and [[metafiction]]. [[Word play]] also features prominently in the work. Puns are occasionally used to connect ideas, such as "the Magnificrab, Indeed" with Bach's ''Magnificat in D''; "[[SHRDLU]], Toy of Man's Designing" with Bach's ''[[Jesu, Joy of Man's Desiring]]''; and "[[Typographical Number Theory]]", or "[[trinitrotoluene|TNT]]", which inevitably reacts explosively when it attempts to make statements about itself. One dialogue contains a story about a genie (from the Arabic "[[Djinn]]") and various "tonics" (of both the [[Tonic water|liquid]] and [[Tonic (music)|musical]] varieties), which is titled "[[Gin and tonic|Djinn and Tonic]]". One dialogue in the book is written in the form of a [[crab canon]], in which every line before the midpoint corresponds to an identical line past the midpoint. The conversation still makes sense due to uses of common phrases that can be used as either greetings or farewells ("Good day") and the positioning of lines that double as an answer to a question in the next line. Another is a sloth canon, where one character repeats the lines of another, but slower and negated. ==Themes== The book contains many instances of [[recursion]] and [[self-reference]], where objects and ideas speak about or refer back to themselves. One is [[Quine (computing)|Quining]], a term Hofstadter invented in homage to [[Willard Van Orman Quine]], referring to programs that only produce their own [[source code]]. Another is the presence of a fictional author in the index, [[Egbert B. Gebstadter]], a man with initials E, G, and B and a surname that partially matches Hofstadter. A phonograph dubbed "Record Player X" destroys itself by playing a record titled ''I Cannot Be Played on Record Player X'' (an analogy to [[Gödel's incompleteness theorems]]), an examination of [[canon (music)|canon]] form in [[music]], and a discussion of Escher's [[Drawing Hands|lithograph of two hands drawing each other]]. To describe such self-referencing objects, Hofstadter coins the term "[[strange loop]]"—a concept he examines in more depth in his follow-up book ''[[I Am a Strange Loop]]''. To escape many of the logical contradictions brought about by these self-referencing objects, Hofstadter discusses [[Zen]] [[koan]]s. He attempts to show readers how to perceive reality outside their own experience and embrace such paradoxical questions by rejecting the premise—a strategy also called [[Mu (negative)|"unasking"]]. Elements of [[computer science]] such as [[call stack]]s are also discussed in ''Gödel, Escher, Bach'', as one dialogue describes the adventures of Achilles and the Tortoise as they make use of "pushing potion" and "popping tonic" involving entering and leaving different layers of reality. Subsequent sections discuss the basic tenets of logic, self-referring statements, ("typeless") systems, and even programming. Hofstadter further creates [[BlooP and FlooP]], two simple [[programming language]]s, to illustrate his point. ==Puzzles== The book is filled with puzzles, such as Hofstadter's [[MU puzzle]]. For example, the chapter titled ''Contracrostipunctus'' combines the words ''[[acrostic]]'' and ''contrapunctus'' ([[counterpoint]]). In a dialogue between Achilles and the Tortoise, the author hints that there is a contrapunctal acrostic in the chapter that refers both to the author (Hofstadter) and Bach. This can be found by taking the first word of each paragraph, to reveal: '''H'''ofstadter's '''C'''ontracrostipunctus '''A'''crostically '''B'''ackwards '''S'''pells ''''J'''. S. Bach'. The second acrostic is found by taking the first letters of the first (in bold) and reading them backwards to get "J. S. Bach" (just as the first acrostic claims). ==Impact== ''Gödel, Escher, Bach'' won the [[Pulitzer Prize]] for general non-fiction{{citation | url = http://www.pulitzer.org/prize-winners-by-year/1980 | title = The Prizes | year = 1980 | publisher = Pulitzer}} and the [[National Book Award]] for Science. [https://www.nationalbook.org/awards-prizes/national-book-awards-1980 "National Book Awards – 1980"]. [[National Book Foundation]]. Retrieved 2012-03-07.This was the [[List of winners of the National Book Award#Science|award for hardcover Science]]. From 1980 to 1983, the [[National Book Award#History|National Book Award history]] gave separate awards to hardcover and paperback books in many categories, including [[National Book Award for Nonfiction|several nonfiction subcategories]]. Most paperback award-winners were reprints of earlier works; the 1980 Science was eligible for both awards as a new book. [[Martin Gardner]]'s July 1979 column in [[Scientific American]] stated, "Every few decades, an unknown author brings out a book of such depth, clarity, range, wit, beauty and originality that it is recognized at once as a major literary event."{{cite web|last=Somers|first=James|title=The Man Who Would Teach Machines to Think|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2013/11/the-man-who-would-teach-machines-to-think/309529/|work=[[The Atlantic]]|publisher=[[The Atlantic Media Company]]|accessdate=25 October 2013}} For Summer 2007, the [[MIT|Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] created an online course for high school students built around the book.{{citation | url = http://ocw.mit.edu/high-school/humanities-and-social-sciences/godel-escher-bach/ | publisher = MIT | title = GEB}} In its February 19, 2010 investigative summary on the [[2001 anthrax attacks]], the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] suggested that [[Bruce Edwards Ivins]] was inspired by the book to hide secret codes based upon [[nucleotide sequence]]s in the [[anthrax]]-laced letters he allegedly sent in September and October 2001,{{cite web |url=http://www.justice.gov/amerithrax/docs/amx-investigative-summary.pdf |title=Amerithrax Investigative Summary |publisher=United States Department of Justice |format=PDF |date=February 19, 2010 |access-date=2010-11-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101128035809/http://www.justice.gov/amerithrax/docs/amx-investigative-summary.pdf |archive-date=2010-11-28 |deadurl=yes}} using bold letters, as suggested on page 404 of the book.{{cite web |url=http://www.justice.gov/amerithrax/docs/j-geb-page-%20404.pdf |title=Page 404 of Godel, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid |format=PDF |publisher=United States Department of Justice |date= |access-date=2010-11-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101128035834/http://www.justice.gov/amerithrax/docs/j-geb-page-%20404.pdf |archive-date=2010-11-28 |deadurl=yes}}[[David Willman|Willman, David]] (2011), ''The Mirage Man: Bruce Ivins, the Anthrax Attacks, and America's Rush to War''; [[New York City|New York]]: [[Bantam Books]], pg 300. It was also suggested that he attempted to hide the book from investigators by throwing it in the trash. ==Translation== Hofstadter claims the idea of translating his book "never crossed [his] mind" when he was writing it—but when his publisher brought it up, he was "very excited about seeing [the] book in other languages, especially… French." He knew, however, that "there were a million issues to consider" when translating,{{harvnb|Hofstadter|1999|p=xxxiv}}. since the book relies not only on word-play, but on "structural puns" as well—writing where the form and content of the work mirror each other (such as the "[[Crab canon]]" dialogue, which reads almost exactly the same forwards as backwards). Hofstadter gives an example of translation trouble in the paragraph "Mr. Tortoise, Meet Madame Tortue", saying translators "instantly ran headlong into the conflict between the feminine gender of the French noun ''tortue'' and the masculinity of my character, the Tortoise." Hofstadter agreed to the translators' suggestions of naming the French character ''Madame Tortue'', and the Italian version ''Signorina Tartaruga''.{{harvnb|Hofstadter|1999|pp=xxxiv–xxxv}}. Because of other troubles translators might have retaining meaning, Hofstadter "painstakingly went through every sentence of ''Gödel, Escher, Bach'', annotating a copy for translators into any language that might be targeted." Translation also gave Hofstadter a way to add new meaning and puns. For instance, in [[Chinese language|Chinese]], the subtitle is not a translation of ''an Eternal Golden Braid'', but a seemingly unrelated phrase ''Jí Yì Bì'' (集异璧, literally "collection of exotic jades"), which is [[homophone|homophonic]] to ''GEB'' in Chinese. Some material regarding this interplay is in Hofstadter's later book, ''[[Le Ton beau de Marot]]'', which is mainly about translation. ==Editions== * {{Citation | last1 = Hofstadter| first1 = Douglas R. | title = Gödel, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid | publisher = Basic Books | year = 1999 | origyear= 1979 | isbn = 0-465-02656-7 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=izy9Tg6rmb8C | accessdate = 2016-03-02 }} ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Chinese room]] * [[Church–Turing thesis]] * [[Collatz conjecture]] - wondrous numbers * [[Fractal]] * [[Heterarchy]] * [[Indra's net]] * [[Isomorphism]] * [[John Lucas (philosopher)]] * [[Meta]] {{div col end}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=lower-alpha}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{OL work}} * [http://ocw.mit.edu/OcwWeb/hs/geb/VideoLectures/index.htm Video lectures from a summer GEB seminar for high schoolers], [[MIT OpenCourseWare]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20161129180504/https://books.google.com/books?id=aFcsnUEewLkC Partial contents of 20th Anniversary Edition] * [http://geb.stenius.org/ Mårten's GEB site] * [http://www-personal.umich.edu/~jlawler/geb.html Class about GEB, at the University of Michigan] * [http://www.uff.br/cdme/triplets/triplets-html/triplets-en.html Java 3D game based on the GEB triplets] * [http://www.scottkim.com/blog/2015/2/12/music-from-gdel-escher-bach Music from Gödel, Escher, Bach]. Escher}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Godel, Escher, Bach}} [[Category:1979 books]] [[Category:Cognitive science literature]] [[Category:Dialogues]] [[Category:M. C. revision.text:
In [[information theory]], the '''information projection''' or '''I-projection''' of a [[probability distribution]] ''q'' onto a set of distributions ''P'' is
:<math>p^* = \underset{p \in P}{\arg\min} \operatorname{D}_{\mathrm{KL}}(p||q)</math>
where <math>D_{\mathrm{KL}}</math> is the [[Kullback–Leibler divergence]] from ''q'' to ''p''. Viewing the Kullback–Leibler divergence as a measure of distance, the I-projection <math>p^*</math> is the "closest" distribution to ''q'' of all the distributions in ''P''.
The I-projection is useful in setting up information geometry, notably because of the following inequality, valid when ''P'' is convex:<ref>{{Cite book |last1 = Cover|first1 = Thomas M.|last2 = Thomas|first2 = Joy A.|title = Elements of Information Theory|publisher = Wiley Interscience|edition = 2|date = 2006|location = Hoboken, New Jersey|pages = 367(theorem 11.6.1)}}</ref>
<math>\operatorname{D}_{\mathrm{KL}}(p||q) \geq \operatorname{D}_{\mathrm{KL}}(p||p^*) + \operatorname{D}_{\mathrm{KL}}(p^*||q)</math>
This inequality can be interpreted as an information-geometric version of Pythagoras' triangle inequality theorem, where KL divergence is viewed as squared distance in a Euclidean space.
It is worthwhile to note that since <math> \operatorname{D}_{\mathrm{KL}}(p||q) \geq 0 </math> and continuous in p, if ''P'' is closed and non-empty, then there exists at least one minimizer to the optimization problem framed above. Furthermore if ''P'' is convex, then the optimum distribution is unique.
The reverse I-projection also known as '''moment projection''' or '''M-projection''' is
<math>p^* = \underset{p \in P}{\arg\min} \operatorname{D}_{\mathrm{KL}}(q||p)</math>
Since the KL divergence is not symmetric in its arguments, the I-projection and the M-projection will exhibit different behavior. For I-projection, <math> p(x) </math> will typically under-estimate the support of <math> q(x) </math> and will lock onto one of its modes. This is due to <math> p(x)=0 </math>, whenever <math> q(x)=0 </math> to make sure KL divergence stays finite. For M-projection, <math> p(x) </math> will typically over-estimate the support of <math> q(x) </math>. This is due to <math> p(x) > 0 </math> whenever <math> q(x) > 0 </math> to make sure KL divergence stays finite.
The concept of information projection can be extended to arbitrary statistical f-divergences and other divergences.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1 = Nielsen|first1 = Frank | title = What is... an information projection?|publisher = AMS |volume =65 | number =3|year = 2018|pages = 321-324|url = http://www.ams.org/journals/notices/201803/rnoti-p321.pdf}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Sanov's theorem]]
==References== {{Reflist}} *K. Murphy, "Machine Learning: a Probabilistic Perspective", The MIT Press, 2012. *F. Nielsen, [http://www.ams.org/journals/notices/201803/rnoti-p321.pdf "What is... an information projection?"], AMS Notices, (65) 3, pp. 321-324, 2018 [[Category:Information theory]]

revision.text:
In [[information theory]] and [[statistics]], '''Kullback's inequality''' is a lower bound on the [[Kullback–Leibler divergence]] expressed in terms of the [[large deviations theory|large deviations]] [[rate function]].<ref>{{cite book |first=Aimé |last=Fuchs |first2=Giorgio |last2=Letta |title=L'inégalité de Kullback. Application à la théorie de l'estimation |series=Séminaire de probabilités |location=Strasbourg |volume=4 |pages=108–131 |year=1970 |url=http://www.numdam.org/item?id=SPS_1970__4__108_0 |isbn= }}</ref> If ''P'' and ''Q'' are [[probability distribution]]s on the real line, such that ''P'' is '''absolutely continuous''' with respect to ''Q'', i.e. ''P''<<''Q'', and whose first moments exist, then :<math>D_{KL}(P\|Q) \ge \Psi_Q^*(\mu'_1(P)),</math> where <math>\Psi_Q^*</math> is the rate function, i.e. the [[convex conjugate]] of the [[cumulant]]-generating function, of <math>Q</math>, and <math>\mu'_1(P)</math> is the first [[Moment (mathematics)|moment]] of <math>P.</math>
The [[Cramér–Rao bound]] is a corollary of this result.
==Proof== Let ''P'' and ''Q'' be [[probability distribution]]s (measures) on the real line, whose first moments exist, and such that [[Absolutely_continuous#Absolute_continuity_of_measures|''P''<<''Q'']]. Consider the '''[[natural exponential family]]''' of ''Q'' given by :<math>Q_\theta(A) = \frac{\int_A e^{\theta x}Q(dx)}{\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{\theta x}Q(dx)} = \frac{1}{M_Q(\theta)} \int_A e^{\theta x}Q(dx)</math> for every measurable set ''A'', where <math>M_Q</math> is the '''[[moment-generating function]]''' of ''Q''. (Note that ''Q''<sub>0</sub>=''Q''.) Then :<math>D_{KL}(P\|Q) = D_{KL}(P\|Q_\theta) + \int_{\mathrm{supp}P}\left(\log\frac{\mathrm dQ_\theta}{\mathrm dQ}\right)\mathrm dP.</math> By [[Gibbs' inequality]] we have <math>D_{KL}(P\|Q_\theta) \ge 0</math> so that :<math>D_{KL}(P\|Q) \ge \int_{\mathrm{supp}P}\left(\log\frac{\mathrm dQ_\theta}{\mathrm dQ}\right)\mathrm dP = \int_{\mathrm{supp}P}\left(\log\frac{e^{\theta x}}{M_Q(\theta)}\right) P(dx)</math> Simplifying the right side, we have, for every real θ where <math>M_Q(\theta) < \infty:</math> :<math>D_{KL}(P\|Q) \ge \mu'_1(P) \theta - \Psi_Q(\theta),</math> where <math>\mu'_1(P)</math> is the first moment, or mean, of ''P'', and <math>\Psi_Q = \log M_Q</math> is called the '''[[cumulant|cumulant-generating function]]'''. Taking the supremum completes the process of [[convex conjugate|convex conjugation]] and yields the [[rate function]]: :<math>D_{KL}(P\|Q) \ge \sup_\theta \left\{ \mu'_1(P) \theta - \Psi_Q(\theta) \right\} = \Psi_Q^*(\mu'_1(P)).</math>
==Corollary: the Cramér–Rao bound== {{main|Cramér–Rao bound}} ===Start with Kullback's inequality=== Let ''X''<sub>θ</sub> be a family of probability distributions on the real line indexed by the real parameter θ, and satisfying certain [[Cramér–Rao_bound#Regularity_conditions|regularity conditions]]. Then :<math> \lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac {D_{KL}(X_{\theta+h}\|X_\theta)} {h^2} \ge \lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac {\Psi^*_\theta (\mu_{\theta+h})}{h^2}, </math>
where <math>\Psi^*_\theta</math> is the [[convex conjugate]] of the [[Cumulant|cumulant-generating function]] of <math>X_\theta</math> and <math>\mu_{\theta+h}</math> is the first moment of <math>X_{\theta+h}.</math>
===Left side=== The left side of this inequality can be simplified as follows:
:<math>\begin{align} \lim_{h\to 0} \frac {D_{KL}(X_{\theta+h}\|X_\theta)} {h^2} &=\lim_{h\to 0} \frac 1 {h^2} \int_{-\infty}^\infty \log \left( \frac{\mathrm dX_{\theta+h}}{\mathrm dX_\theta} \right) \mathrm dX_{\theta+h} \\ &=\lim_{h\to 0} \frac 1 {h^2} \int_{-\infty}^\infty \log\left( 1- \left (1-\frac{\mathrm dX_{\theta+h}}{\mathrm dX_\theta} \right ) \right) \mathrm dX_{\theta+h} \\ &= \lim_{h\to 0} \frac 1 {h^2} \int_{-\infty}^\infty \left[ \left( 1 - \frac{\mathrm dX_\theta}{\mathrm dX_{\theta+h}} \right) +\frac 1 2 \left( 1 - \frac{\mathrm dX_\theta}{\mathrm dX_{\theta+h}} \right) ^ 2 + o \left( \left( 1 - \frac{\mathrm dX_\theta}{\mathrm dX_{\theta+h}} \right) ^ 2 \right) \right]\mathrm dX_{\theta+h} && \text{Taylor series for } \log(1-t) \\ &= \lim_{h\to 0} \frac 1 {h^2} \int_{-\infty}^\infty \left[ \frac 1 2 \left( 1 - \frac{\mathrm dX_\theta}{\mathrm dX_{\theta+h}} \right)^2 \right]\mathrm dX_{\theta+h} \\ &= \lim_{h\to 0} \frac 1 {h^2} \int_{-\infty}^\infty \left[ \frac 1 2 \left( \frac{\mathrm dX_{\theta+h} - \mathrm dX_\theta}{\mathrm dX_{\theta+h}} \right)^2 \right]\mathrm dX_{\theta+h} \\ &= \frac 1 2 \mathcal I_X(\theta) \end{align}</math> which is half the [[Fisher information]] of the parameter θ.
===Right side=== The right side of the inequality can be developed as follows: :<math> \lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac {\Psi^*_\theta (\mu_{\theta+h})}{h^2} = \lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac 1 {h^2} {\sup_t \{\mu_{\theta+h}t - \Psi_\theta(t)\} }. </math> This supremum is attained at a value of ''t''=τ where the first derivative of the cumulant-generating function is <math>\Psi'_\theta(\tau) = \mu_{\theta+h},</math> but we have <math>\Psi'_\theta(0) = \mu_\theta,</math> so that :<math>\Psi''_\theta(0) = \frac{d\mu_\theta}{d\theta} \lim_{h \rightarrow 0} \frac h \tau.</math> Moreover, :<math>\lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac {\Psi^*_\theta (\mu_{\theta+h})}{h^2} = \frac 1 {2\Psi''_\theta(0)}\left(\frac {d\mu_\theta}{d\theta}\right)^2 = \frac 1 {2\mathrm{Var}(X_\theta)}\left(\frac {d\mu_\theta}{d\theta}\right)^2.</math> ===Putting both sides back together=== We have: :<math>\frac 1 2 \mathcal I_X(\theta) \ge \frac 1 {2\mathrm{Var}(X_\theta)}\left(\frac {d\mu_\theta}{d\theta}\right)^2,</math> which can be rearranged as: :<math>\mathrm{Var}(X_\theta) \ge \frac{(d\mu_\theta / d\theta)^2} {\mathcal I_X(\theta)}.</math>
==See also== * [[Kullback–Leibler divergence]] * [[Cramér–Rao bound]] * [[Fisher information]] * [[Large deviations theory]] * [[Convex conjugate]] * [[Rate function]] * [[Moment-generating function]]
==Notes and references== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kullback's Inequality}} [[Category:Information theory]] [[Category:Statistical inequalities]] [[Category:Estimation theory]]

In chemistry, '''ligand close packing theory''' ('''LCP theory'''), sometimes called the '''ligand close packing model''' describes how [[ligand]] – [[ligand]] repulsions affect the geometry around a central atom.<ref name=GillespieMatta2001>''Teaching the VSEPR model and electron densities'' R. J. Gillespie and C. F. Matta, Chem. Educ. Res. Pract. Eur.: 2001, 2, 73-90</ref> It has been developed by [[R. J. Gillespie]] and others from 1997 onwards <ref name = robinsonGillespie1997>Reinterpretation of the Lengths of Bonds to Fluorine in Terms of an Almost Ionic Model E A. Robinson , S A. Johnson, Ting-Hua Tang, and R J. Gillespie Inorg. Chem., 36 (14), 3022 -3030, 1997. ic961315b S0020-1669(96)01315-8</ref> and is said to sit alongside [[VSEPR]]<ref name=GillespieMatta2001/> which was originally developed by [[Ronald Gillespie|R. J. Gillespie]] and [[R.S. Nyholm|R Nyholm]].<ref name=GillespieNyholm1957>''Inorganic stereochemistry'' Gillespie, R.J. & Nyholm, R.S. (1957). Quarterly Reviews of the Chemical Society, 11, 339-380 {{doi|10.1039/QR9571100339}}</ref> The inter-ligand distances in a wide range of molecules have been determined. The example below shows a series of related molecules:<ref name= GillespieRobinson1998>''Bonding and Geometry of OCF<sub>3</sub><sup><nowiki>−</nowiki></sup>, ONF<sub>3</sub>, and Related Molecules in Terms of the Ligand Close Packing Model'' Gillespie RJ, Robinson EA, Heard GL. Inorg Chem. 1998 Dec 28;37(26):6884-6889 {{doi|10.1021/ic981037b}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! ! F-F distance (pm) ! O-F distance (pm) ! C-F bond length (pm) ! C=O bond length (pm) |- | CF<sub>4</sub> | 216 | | 132 | |- | O=CF<sub>3</sub><sup><nowiki>−</nowiki></sup> | 216 | 223 | 139 | 123 |- | O=CF<sub>2</sub> | 216 | 222 | 132 | 117 |} The consistency of the interligand distances (F-F and O-F) in the above molecules is striking and this phenomenon is repeated across a wide range of molecules and forms the basis for LCP theory.
==Ligand radius== From a study of known structural data a series of inter-ligand distances has been determined<ref name=GillespieMatta2001/> and it has been found that there is a constant inter-ligand radius for a given central atom. The table below shows the inter-ligand radius (pm) for some of the period 2 elements:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Ligand ! Beryllium ! Boron ! Carbon ! Nitrogen |- | H | | 110 | 90 | 82 |- | C | | 137 | 125 | 120 |- | N | 144 | 124 | 119 | |- | O | 133 | 119 | 114 | |- | F | 128 | 113 | 108 | 106 |- | Cl | 168 | 151 | 144 | 142 |} The ligand radius should not be confused with the [[ionic radius]].
==Treatment of lone pairs== In LCP theory a lone pair is treated as a ligand. Gillespie terms the lone pair a lone pair domain and states that these lone pair domains push the ligands together until they reach the interligand distance predicted by the relevant inter-ligand radii.<ref name=GillespieMatta2001/> An example demonstrating this is shown below, where the F-F distance is the same in the AF<sub>3</sub> and AF<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup> species : {| class="wikitable" |- ! ! F-F distance (pm) ! A-F bond length (pm) ! F-A-F angle (degrees) |- | NF<sub>3</sub> | 212 | 136.5 | 102.3 |- | NF<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup> | 212 | 130 | 109.5 |- | PF<sub>3</sub> | 237 | 157 | 97.8 |- | PF<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup> | 238 | 145.7 | 109.5 |}
==LCP and VSEPR== LCP and VSEPR make very similar predictions as to geometry but LCP theory has the advantage that predictions are more quantitative particularly for the second period elements, Be, B, C, N, O, F. Ligand -ligand repulsions are important when<ref name=GillespieMatta2001/> *the central atom is small e.g. period 2, (Be, B, C, N, O) *the ligands are only weakly electronegative compared to the central atom *the ligands are large compared to the central atom * there are 5 or more ligands around the central atom

during Asian Games 2018''}} |- |} === Australia === On August 15, 2018, Telstra activated its 5G network on the Gold Coast, Australia making it the first global telecommunications provider to bring a commercial 5G network to market. In February 2018, Telstra had demonstrated that its 5G network could achieve download speeds of 3Gbit/s and a ping of just 6ms.{{Cite news|url=https://www.news.com.au/technology/gadgets/mobile-phones/telstra-draws-first-blood-in-battle-for-5g/news-story/960bba3d49d05d3356cee0c4bb25cddc|title=Telstra draws first blood in battle for 5G|last=|first=|date=|work=news.com.au|access-date=2018-09-20}} Optus has announced that it will launch its 5G network in early 2019.{{Cite news|url=https://www.finder.com.au/optus-will-launch-its-5g-network-in-early-2019|title=Optus will launch its 5G network in early 2019 {{!}} finder.com.au|last=Kidman|first=Alex|date=2018-02-02|work=finder.com.au|access-date=2018-09-20|language=en-US}} === Finland and Estonia === On June 27, 2018, [[Elisa (company)|Elisa]], a Finnish telecommunications company, launched the world's first commercial 5G network in [[Tampere|Tampere, Finland]] and [[Tallinn|Tallinn, Estonia]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.epressi.com/tiedotteet/telekommunikaatio/elisa-first-in-world-to-launch-commercial-5g.html?customer=657|title=Elisa first in world to launch commercial 5G |publisher= ePressi|access-date=2018-06-29|language=fi}} === Latvia === On March 21, 2017, [[Latvian Mobile Telephone|LMT]], launched the world's first 5G network in [[Riga|Riga, Latvia]].{{Cite news|url=https://eng.lsm.lv/article/economy/economy/first-5g-station-opens-in-riga.a229257/|title=First 5G station opens in Riga |publisher=LSM|access-date=2017-03-22|language=lv}} ===Lesotho=== Vodacom announced on August 25, 2018, that they have launched the first 5G commercial network in Africa in Lesotho. It will be used to provide fixed connectivity to two corporate clients in the country. The network operates on the 3.5 GHz spectrum. 700Mbit/s speeds have been achieved.{{Cite news|url=https://techcentral.co.za/vodacom-launches-commercial-5g-in-lesotho/83317/|title=Vodacom launches commercial 5G – in Lesotho |date=2018-08-25|work=TechCentral|access-date=2018-08-27|language=en-US}} === Philippines === {{as of|2018|June|25|df=US}}, [[Smart Communications]] claimed to have the fastest 5G network.{{cite web |title=Smart notches 5G speeds of over 14Gbps |url=https://smart.com.ph/About/newsroom/full-news/2018/06/25/smart-notches-5g-speeds-of-over-14gbps |website=Smart Communications |publisher=[[Smart Communications]] |accessdate=25 June 2018 |location=Philippines}} First 5G sites have been established in the cities of Manila and Clark. === Switzerland === On November 8, 2018, [[Swisscom]] presented the worldwide first 5G smartphone prototype featuring a [[Qualcomm]] 5G midband modem to a live 5G test network in Lucerne{{Cite web|url=https://www.swisscom.ch/en/about/medien/press-releases/2018/11/20181108-mm-5g-smartphone-prototyp.html|title=Swisscom presents first 5G smartphone prototype on 5G network {{!}} Swisscom|website=www.swisscom.ch|language=en|access-date=2018-11-27}}  {{Cite news|url=https://www.qualcomm.com/news/releases/2018/11/08/qualcomm-swisscom-wnc-and-ericsson-successfully-achieve-worlds-first-5g-nr|title=Qualcomm, Swisscom, WNC and Ericsson Successfully Achieve World’s First 5G NR Sub-6 GHz OTA Connection on Live Network with a 5G Device {{!}} Qualcomm|work=Qualcomm|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en}}. At the same time, a hotspot from Taiwan company WNC featuring the identical modem was also connected to the live 5G network {{Cite web|url=https://www.swisscom.ch/en/about/medien/press-releases/2018/11/20181108-mm-5g-smartphone-prototyp.html|title=Swisscom presents first 5G smartphone prototype on 5G network {{!}} Swisscom|website=www.swisscom.ch|language=en|access-date=2018-11-27}}. This was the first 5G NR OTA (New Radio Over-the-Air) connection worldwide between devices and a live operator network using 3.5 GHz spectrum{{Cite news|url=https://www.qualcomm.com/news/releases/2018/11/08/qualcomm-swisscom-wnc-and-ericsson-successfully-achieve-worlds-first-5g-nr|title=Qualcomm, Swisscom, WNC and Ericsson Successfully Achieve World’s First 5G NR Sub-6 GHz OTA Connection on Live Network with a 5G Device {{!}} Qualcomm|work=Qualcomm|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en}} {{Cite web|url=https://www.ericsson.com/en/news/2018/11/5g-devices-nearer-to-reality-thanks-to-swisscom-ericsson-qualcomm-wnc|title=5G devices closer as Ericsson, Qualcomm, Swisscom, WNC achieve landmark|website=Ericsson.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-27}} . The demo was performed in collaboration with vendor partner Ericsson, [[Qualcomm Technologies]] and Wistron NeWeb Corporation (WNC){{Cite news|url=https://www.mobileworldlive.com/featured-content/home-banner/swisscom-qualcomm-demo-mobile-5g/|title=Swisscom, Qualcomm demo mobile 5G - Mobile World Live|date=2018-11-08|work=Mobile World Live|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en-GB}} . On September 3, 2018, [[Swisscom]] completed Europe's first end-to-end 5G data transfers on their complete 5G network in Burgdorf based on the latest 5G standard 3GPP{{Cite web|url=https://www.swisscom.ch/en/about/medien/press-releases/2018/09/20180904-5g-netz-in-burgdorf.html|title=Swisscom: first completely standardized 5G network in Burgdorf {{!}} Swisscom|website=www.swisscom.ch|language=en|access-date=2018-11-27}}. With a 5G-capable device from Intel (Intel® 5G Mobile Trial Platform), the first mobile data transmissions were successfully carried out on a purely 5G network and applications such as web browsing, voice connections and streaming were tested{{Cite news|url=https://www.computerworld.ch/business/telekommunikation/swisscom-testet-5g-netz-in-burgdorf-1578461.html|title=Swisscom testet 5G-Netz in Burgdorf|last=Computerworld.ch|work=Computerworld.ch|access-date=2018-11-27|language=de-DE}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.swisscom.ch/en/about/medien/press-releases/2018/09/20180904-5g-netz-in-burgdorf.html|title=Swisscom: first completely standardized 5G network in Burgdorf {{!}} Swisscom|website=www.swisscom.ch|language=en|access-date=2018-11-27}}. === United Kingdom === [[EE Limited|EE]], a large mobile network operator in the UK, plans to trial a 5G network in October 2018. A small number of businesses and homes in [[East London Tech City]] will take part in the trial.{{cite news|url=https://www.techradar.com/news/ee-to-switch-on-uks-first-5g-trial-in-london|title=EE to switch on 'UK's first' 5G trial in London|first1=Steve|last1=McCaskill|date=June 6, 2018|work=TechRadar|accessdate=6 June 2018}} [[BT Group]], who owns EE, had previously said during a presentation in May 2018 that they plan to launch a commercial 5G product "within 18 months".{{cite news|url=https://www.pocket-lint.com/phones/news/bt/144518-bt-will-be-first-to-launch-uk-5g-in-2019|title=BT will be first to launch UK 5G in 2019|first1=Chris|last1=Hall|date=May 16, 2018|work=Pocket-lint|accessdate=6 June 2018}} The [[UK]] first plans to deploy 5G to [[London]] and other major cities (e.g., [[Bristol]], [[Birmingham]]) as a starting point, and then it will establish a 5G network in other major cities. The next step will be for small- and medium-sized towns.{{cite web|url=https://5g.co.uk/coverage/|title=5G Coverage and Networks|website=5g.co.uk}} === United States === US operators' launch plans fall into two distinct categories: Fixed wireless and mobile. Fixed wireless typically services residential broadband customers with speeds in excess of 1 Gbit/s using mmWave bands. Mobile launch will use sub-6 GHz spectrum in traditional LTE or newly-allocated bands with similar performance to LTE. {| class="wikitable" |+ ! ! colspan="3" |Fixed wireless ! colspan="3" |Mobile |- revision.text:
{{For|reserves excluding gold|List of countries by foreign-exchange reserves (excluding gold)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} '''[[Foreign-exchange reserves]]''' (also called '''Forex reserves''') are, in a strict sense, ''only'' the foreign-currency deposits held by national [[central bank]]s and [[monetary authority|monetary authorities]] (''See'' [[List of countries by foreign-exchange reserves (excluding gold)]]). However, in '''popular usage and in the list below''', it also includes [[gold reserve]]s, [[special drawing rights]] (SDRs) and [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF) reserve position because this total figure, which is usually more accurately termed as '''official reserves''' or '''international reserves''' or '''official international reserves''', is more readily available. These foreign-currency deposits are the [[financial asset]]s of the central banks and monetary authorities that are held in different [[reserve currency|reserve currencies]] (e.g. the [[United States dollar|U.S. dollar]], the [[Euro]], the [[Japanese yen]] and the [[Pound sterling]]) and which are used to back its liabilities (e.g. the local currency issued and the various [[bank reserves]] [[deposit account|deposited]] with the central bank by the [[government]] or [[financial institution]]s). Before the end of the [[gold standard]], gold was the preferred reserve currency. Some nations are converting foreign-exchange reserves into [[sovereign wealth fund]]s, which can rival foreign-exchange reserves in size. The list below is mostly based on the latest available IMF data, and while most nations report in U.S. dollars, a few nations in [[Eastern Europe]] report solely in Euros. And since all the figures below are in U.S. dollar equivalence, [[exchange rate]] fluctuations can have a significant impact on these figures. ==Foreign-exchange reserves== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="float:left; border:1px solid #999;" |- ! Rank ! Country or region ! Foreign-exchange reserves
(Millions of [[United States dollar|US$]]) ! The data are reported to the IMF on a voluntary and confidential basis. As of Q4 2016, there are 146 reporters, consisting of IMF member countries, a number of non-member countries/economies, and other entities holding foreign exchange reserves. From Q4 2016, the data was expanded to include renminbi (RMB).{{cite web|url=http://data.imf.org/?sk=E6A5F467-C14B-4AA8-9F6D-5A09EC4E62A4|title=IMF Data - Currency Composition of Official Foreign Exchange Reserves (COFER)|last=|first=|date=March 30, 2018|website=|publisher=International Monetary Fund|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} {|class=wikitable style="text-align:right;" |- |+Currency Composition of Foreign Exchange Reserves (COFER)

page.title: List of countries by unemployment rate

revision.comment: updated for EU, Norway, Iceland, USA, Kenya, India with appropriate citations to reliable sources
revision.text:
[[File:Unemployment rate map of the world (ILO).svg|thumb|Unemployment rate per country in 2013]] This is a '''list of countries by unemployment rate'''. Methods of calculation and presentation of [[unemployment rate]] vary from country to country. Some countries count insured unemployed only, some count those in receipt of welfare benefit only, some count the disabled and other permanently unemployable people, some countries count those who choose (and are financially able) not to work, supported by their spouses and caring for a family, some count students at college and so on. There may also be differences in the minimum requirements and some consider people employed even if only marginally associated with employment market (for example, working only one hour per week).{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/189068/bls-unemployment-seasonally-adjusted.aspx|title=Real Unemployment -- Department of Labor (U-6)|work=Gallup|access-date=1 September 2017|date=August 2017}} There can be differences in the age limit. For example, [[Eurostat]] uses 15 to 74 years old when calculating unemployment rate, and the [[Bureau of Labor Statistics]] uses anyone 16 years of age or older (in both cases, people who are under education, retired, on maternity/paternity leave, prevented from working due to health, or do not work but have been inactive in seeking employment in the last four weeks are excluded from the [[workforce]], and therefore not counted as unemployed).{{cite web| url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/Unemployment_statistics | title=Unemployment statistics | work=Eurostat | access-date=1 September 2017 | date=August 2017}}{{cite web| url=https://www.bls.gov/cps/cps_htgm.htm | title=Labor Force Statistics from the Current Population Survey – How the Government Measures Unemployment | work=Bureau of Labor Statistics | access-date=1 September 2017 | date=8 October 2015}} Unemployment rates are often [[seasonally adjusted]] to avoid variations that depend on time of year. [[List of countries by employment rate|Employment rate as a percentage of total population in working age]] is sometimes used instead of unemployment rate. For purposes of comparison, harmonized values are published by [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO) and by [[OECD]]. The ILO harmonized unemployment rate refers to those who are currently not working but are willing and able to work for pay, currently available to work, and have actively searched for work. The OECD harmonized unemployment rate gives the number of unemployed persons as a percentage of the labour force. {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ |- style="background:#ececec; vertical-align:top;" !Name of Countries!! data-sort-type="number" | Unemployment rate (%) !! page.title: List of features removed in Windows XP

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Windows XP}}
As the next version of [[Windows NT]] after [[Windows 2000]], as well as the successor to [[Windows Me]], [[Windows XP]] introduced many [[Features new to Windows XP|new features]] but it also removed some others. Following is a list of these.
==Shell== * The unsafe device removal dialog was removed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.msdn.com/b/oldnewthing/archive/2003/12/16/43890.aspx|title=The unsafe device removal dialog|last=Chen|first=Raymond|date=December 16, 2003|work=The Old New Thing|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|accessdate=July 9, 2013}}</ref> * The ''Line Up Icons'' command on the [[Desktop environment|desktop]] is no longer available. It is replaced by the ''Align to Grid'' option.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/293478 |title=Line Up Icons Command Is Missing on Windows XP Desktop |date=January 27, 2006 |work=Support |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |accessdate=November 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214094553/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/293478 |archivedate=December 14, 2007 |df= }}</ref> Due to this being a toggle, simply aligning desktop icons once without further constraining their placement requires an extra [[Point and click|click]].<ref name="karp2005">{{cite book|title=Windows XP in a Nutshell|first1=David A.|last1=Karp|first2=Tim|last2=O'Reilly|first3=Troy|last3=Mott|publisher=O'Reilly Media, Inc.|location=Sebastopol, CA|year=2005|isbn=0596009003|accessdate=November 7, 2012|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5_UoYcmkvncC&lpg=PP1&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false|edition=2nd}}</ref>{{rp|47}} * The ''Minimize all windows'' command on the [[Taskbar#Microsoft Windows|taskbar]] is hidden.<ref name="karp2005" />{{rp|76}} The purported replacement, ''Show the desktop'', co-existed with this feature on Windows 2000 and in any case only hides [[Window (computing)|windows]] temporarily instead of actually minimizing them. It is still accessible through the {{keypress|[[Windows key|Win]]|M}} [[keyboard shortcut]] but it is not available through the [[Mouse (computing)|mouse]]. * The ''Show icons using all possible colors'' option in ''Display Properties'' is no longer available. Icons are always shown using all possible colors. Microsoft states that this is by design.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/282432 |title="Show icons using all possible colors" Option Is Not Available |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=January 15, 2006 |work=Support |accessdate=November 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090112125824/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/282432 |archivedate=January 12, 2009 |df= }}</ref> * The [[VGA]] [[screen resolution]] and [[color depth#8-bit color|8-bit color depth]] options have been removed from the ''Settings'' tab of ''Display Properties''. It is still possible to select these options using the ''Advanced'' button available under this tab, but Microsoft states that this workaround is unsupported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/286906 |title=Cannot Change Display Setting to 640 X 480 or 256 Color |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=January 15, 2006 |work=Support |accessdate=January 26, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070219235217/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/286906 |archivedate=February 19, 2007 |df= }}</ref> * In the [[cmd.exe|Command Prompt]], ''QuickEdit mode'' and ''Insert mode'' are disabled by default and can only be re-enabled per window title.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/282301 |title=Command Prompt QuickEdit Mode Is Disabled by Default in Windows XP |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=January 15, 2006 |work=Support |accessdate=January 26, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071216132559/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/282301 |archivedate=December 16, 2007 |df= }}</ref> * Links to ''Phone Dialer''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/285920 |title=Phone Dialer Is Not Available in the Communications Menu |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=January 15, 2006 |work=Support |accessdate=January 26, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070312222148/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/285920 |archivedate=March 12, 2007 |df= }}</ref> and [[NetMeeting]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/298327 |title=NetMeeting Is Not Available on the Windows XP "Communications" Menu |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=January 25, 2006 |work=Support |accessdate=January 26, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061208214314/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/298327 |archivedate=December 8, 2006 |df= }}</ref> were removed from the [[Start menu]].
==Personalization== * With the ''Desktop Themes'' utility in 2000 becoming the ''Themes'' tab in ''Display Properties'' in XP, the ''Rotate theme monthly'' option in ''Desktop Themes'', which was introduced in [[Microsoft Plus! 98]] and later included in Windows 2000, and both the options to select what parts of a theme to apply and the previews for parts of a theme were removed. * It is no longer possible to save or delete schemes under the ''Appearance'' tab of ''Display Properties''. * The option to select a ''Pattern'' under the ''Background'' (2000)/''Desktop'' (XP) tab of ''Display Properties'' was removed. * The ''3D Maze'' (possibly due to the [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] [[logo]] having been changed, although the [[Wingdings]] [[font]] with the old Windows logo is still present) and ''Channel Screen Saver'' [[screensaver]]s were removed. The ''3D Pipes'' [[teapot]] [[Easter egg (media)|easter egg]] also no longer works on Windows XP.
==Windows Explorer== * ''Small Icons'' view is no longer available in [[File Explorer (Windows)|Windows Explorer]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://winsupersite.com/article/windows-7/windows-7-feature-focus-windows-explorer|title=Windows 7 Feature Focus: Windows Explorer|last=Thurrott|first=Paul|date=October 6, 2010|work=SuperSite for Windows|publisher=[[Penton (company)|Penton]]|accessdate=November 30, 2012}}</ref> * ''Web view'' in [[Folder (computing)|folders]] was disabled by default but can be reinstated by editing the [[Windows Registry|registry]]. Additionally, the ''Customize This Folder Wizard'' was removed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/819028 |title=Windows Explorer no longer displays Web view templates or HTML customizations (using Folder.htt) |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=October 10, 2003 |work=Support |accessdate=November 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041020044404/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/819028 |archivedate=October 20, 2004 |df= }}</ref> Due to the removal of ''Web view'', [[pie chart]]s showing disk space are no longer available immediately upon opening a drive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.annoyances.org/exec/forum/winxp/t1094485009|title=Free space pie chart missing?|author=JCMIT|date=September 6, 2004|work=Annoyances.org|accessdate=December 15, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050126211909/http://www.annoyances.org/exec/forum/winxp/t1094485009|archivedate=January 26, 2005}}</ref> * The [[status bar]] no longer shows the free space remaining on the given disk when browsing through folder paths of shell namespace extensions,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.annoyances.org/exec/forum/winxp/t1104332485|title='Disk Free Space' not displayed in Windows Explorer UNLESS viewing files under Desktop > My Computer > C:|author=aeneas kaolin|date=December 29, 2004|work=Annoyances.org|accessdate=December 11, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050106062702/http://annoyances.org/exec/forum/winxp/t1104332485|archivedate=January 6, 2005}}</ref> removable drives,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsgroups.derkeiler.com/Archive/Alt/alt.os.windows-xp/2006-06/msg00442.html|title=Free space no listed in status bar for removable drives|author=ranvel|date=June 11, 2006|work=derkeiler.com|accessdate=January 22, 2013}}</ref> and network shares when the navigation pane (''Folders'') in Windows Explorer is turned on, unlike in Windows 2000. It continues to show the free space remaining only for paths on local drives. In combination with the ''Web view''-related lack of pie charts previously mentioned, this means it is no longer possible to immediately view the amount of space remaining in these three cases. * The ''Directory'' icon was removed from ''My Network Places''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/329495 |title=The Directory icon in Entire Network in My Network Places is missing |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=March 15, 2005 |work=Support |accessdate=November 8, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629142610/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/329495 |archivedate=June 29, 2007 |df= }}</ref> * The default sort order in Windows Explorer has changed but can be restored by editing the registry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/319827 |title=The sort order for files and folders whose names contain numerals is different in Windows Vista, Windows XP, and Windows Server 2003 than it is in Windows 2000 |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=August 28, 2007 |work=Support |accessdate=December 4, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071117045047/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/319827 |archivedate=November 17, 2007 |df= }}</ref>
==Bundled applications== * [[CD Player (Windows)#Deluxe CD Player|Deluxe CD Player]], which was also first part of Microsoft Plus! 98 before being included in Windows 2000, was removed.<ref name="kb284971">{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/284971 |title=Unable to Locate Either CD Deluxe or CD Player Playlists in Windows Media Player |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=February 28, 2014 |edition=6.3 |work=Support |accessdate=November 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407081910/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/284971 |archivedate=April 7, 2014 |df= }}</ref> Some functionality, including [[upload]]ing<ref>{{cite web|url=http://winsupersite.com/article/windows-95/plus-for-windows-98-reviewed-127376|title=Plus! for Windows 98 Review|last=Thurrott|first=Paul|date=June 25, 1998|work=SuperSite for Windows|publisher=[[Penton (company)|Penton]]|accessdate=November 7, 2012}}</ref> and [[Code on demand|on-demand]] (as opposed to automatic) [[downloading]] of [[audio track]] information and track previewing was not available in the replacement, [[Windows Media Player]]. * [[DVD Player (Windows)|DVD Player]] is no longer usable as it is now a [[Method stub|stub]] that simply opens Windows Media Player. * [[Imaging for Windows]] was removed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/308979 |title=Kodak imaging for Windows is not included with Windows XP |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=March 22, 2007 |work=Support |accessdate=November 7, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016061201/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/308979 |archivedate=October 16, 2007 |df= }}</ref> It was replaced by the [[Windows Photo Viewer|Windows Picture and Fax Viewer]] and ''Scanner and Camera Wizard'' but these two [[Computer program|programs]] do not include some of its advanced functionality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilixis.com/developer/kodak_history.html |title=Kodak/Wang Image OCX Controls | Some History |publisher=Ilixis |date=February 29, 2012 |accessdate=April 16, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229031646/http://www.ilixis.com/developer/kodak_history.html |archivedate=February 29, 2012 }}</ref>
==Protocols== * [[NetDDE]]<ref name="ee449431">{{cite web|url=https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ee449431.aspx|title=Understanding Application Compatibility|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|work=[[Microsoft TechNet|TechNet]]|accessdate=November 8, 2012}}</ref> and [[NetBIOS Frames protocol|NetBEUI]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/301041 |title=How to install NetBEUI on Windows XP |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=June 23, 2005 |work=Support |accessdate=November 8, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050913162658/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/301041 |archivedate=September 13, 2005 |df= }}</ref> are no longer installed by default but can still be manually installed from the Windows XP [[CD-ROM]]. * The [[Data Link Control|DLC]] [[Communications protocol|network protocol]] is no longer included. A download was made available by [[Microsoft]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/306037 |title=The DLC Protocol Is Not Available in Windows XP |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=October 11, 2002 |work=Support |accessdate=November 8, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050409045044/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/306037 |archivedate=April 9, 2005 |df= }}</ref> * The [[AppleTalk]] protocol is no longer included.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/305989 |title=The AppleTalk Protocol Is Not Available in Windows XP |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=October 18, 2001 |work=Support |accessdate=November 8, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050409044803/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/305989 |archivedate=April 9, 2005 |df= }}</ref>
==Subsystems== * The [[POSIX]] subsystem was removed.<ref name="gg463468">{{cite web|url=http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/hardware/gg463468.aspx|title=Kernel Enhancements for Windows XP|publisher=Microsoft|date=January 13, 2003|work=[[MSDN]]|accessdate=April 16, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130306034824/http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/hardware/gg463468.aspx|archivedate=March 6, 2013}}</ref> [[Windows Services for UNIX]] is available as a replacement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/308259 |title=POSIX and OS/2 are not supported in Windows XP or in Windows Server 2003 |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=May 12, 2004 |work=Support |accessdate=May 21, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041019061658/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/308259 |archivedate=October 19, 2004 |df= }}</ref> * The [[OS/2]] subsystem was removed.<ref name="gg463468" />
==Hardware support== * Support for non-[[Legacy Plug and Play|Plug and Play]] [[Networking hardware|networking devices]], such as [[modem]]s and [[Network interface controller|NICs]], and native support for modems slower than 28.8 [[Data rate units|kbps]] was removed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/295745 |title=Non-Plug and Play Network Device Support in Windows XP |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=October 18, 2001 |work=Support |accessdate=November 8, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041030215121/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/295745 |archivedate=October 30, 2004 |df= }}</ref> * A number of [[SCSI host adapter]]s are no longer supported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/270650 |title=SCSI Host Adapters Removed from Windows XP |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=January 27, 2006 |work=Support |accessdate=November 8, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070713193006/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/270650 |archivedate=July 13, 2007 |df= }}</ref> * Windows XP drops support for [[NEC]]'s [[PC-9800 series|PC-98 series]] and [[Silicon Graphics]]' [[SGI Visual Workstation|Visual Workstation 320 and 540]].<ref name="gg463468" /> * New [[Printer (computing)|printer]] installations are required to use [[Ring (computer security)|user-mode]] rendering [[Software component|component]]s.<ref name="ee449431" />
==Windows 9x== * [[WebTV for Windows]] was removed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.microsoft.com/whdc/archive/broadcast.mspx |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040725120714/http://www.microsoft.com/whdc/archive/broadcast.mspx |title=TV and Broadcast Driver Architecture |work=WHDC |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |archivedate=July 25, 2004 |accessdate=May 21, 2014}}</ref> * [[DriveSpace]] was removed in favour of native [[NTFS compression]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/316639 |title=How to prepare to upgrade Windows 98 or Windows Millennium Edition to Windows XP |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=March 5, 2013 |work=Support |accessdate=May 21, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130306083415/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/316639 |archivedate=March 6, 2013 |df= }}</ref> * The [[NTBackup]] tool included in Windows XP does not support certain backup formats available for use in the ''MSBackup'' tool in [[Windows 9x]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/305381 |title=Cannot Restore Backups That You Create in Windows 95, Windows 98, or Windows Me with the Windows XP Ntbackup Tool |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=May 7, 2007 |work=Support |accessdate=May 21, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070818233655/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/305381 |archivedate=August 18, 2007 |df= }}</ref> * A number of [[MS-DOS]] commands are no longer supported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.microsoft.com/resources/documentation/windows/xp/all/proddocs/en-us/dos_diffs.mspx?mfr=true |title=New ways to do familiar tasks |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |work=Windows XP Product Documentation |accessdate=May 21, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060503205403/http://www.microsoft.com/resources/documentation/windows/xp/all/proddocs/en-us/dos_diffs.mspx?mfr=true |archivedate=May 3, 2006 |df= }}</ref>
==Later versions== ===Service Pack 2=== * The following [[raw socket]] functionality was removed: sending [[Transmission Control Protocol|TCP]] [[network packet]]s, sending [[User Datagram Protocol|UDP]] packets with invalid source [[network address]]es, and associating local addresses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms740548.aspx|title=TCP/IP Raw Sockets (Windows)|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|work=[[MSDN]]|accessdate=November 7, 2012|archiveurl=https://archive.is/q45GA|archivedate=2013-01-28|deadurl=no}}</ref> * The number of [[TCP half-open]] connections was restricted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.microsoft.com/products/ee/transform.aspx?ProdName=Windows+Operating+System&EvtID=4226&EvtSrc=Tcpip |title=Source: Tcpip ID: 4226 (Windows Operating System ) - Events And Errors Message Center: Message Details |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |accessdate=November 8, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529043926/http://www.microsoft.com/products/ee/transform.aspx?ProdName=Windows%2BOperating%2BSystem&EvtID=4226&EvtSrc=Tcpip |archivedate=May 29, 2014 |df= }}</ref> * [[Program Manager]] was removed. * ''Media Bar'', which replaced the ''Radio Toolbar'' in [[Internet Explorer 6]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/303130 |title=The Radio Toolbar Is Unavailable in Internet Explorer 6 |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=January 31, 2007 |work=Support |accessdate=November 8, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080309210019/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/303130 |archivedate=March 9, 2008 |df= }}</ref> was removed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms533100.aspx|title=Media Bar|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|work=[[MSDN]]|accessdate=November 8, 2012}}</ref> * [[Background process|Background]] [[Email|message]] [[Data compaction|compaction]] was removed from [[Outlook Express]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insideoe.com/files/maintain.htm|title=Inside Outlook Express - Files and Settings - Maintenance Part I|last=Koch|first=Tom|date=April 29, 2006|work=Inside Outlook Express|accessdate=November 7, 2012}}</ref> Outlook Express in Service Pack 2 automatically compacts messages every hundredth time it is run.
===Service Pack 3=== * The ''Address bar'' [[toolbar]] on the [[Taskbar#Microsoft Windows|taskbar]] was removed for legal reasons, according to Microsoft. [[Windows Desktop Search]] is touted as a replacement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/951448 |title=The Address toolbar no longer appears on the taskbar after you install Windows XP Service Pack 3 |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=May 6, 2008 |work=Support |accessdate=November 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513075458/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/951448 |archivedate=May 13, 2008 |df= }}</ref> * The option to display the special [[Internet Explorer]] icon on the desktop was removed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tipandtrick.net/restore-missing-or-disappeared-ie-internet-explorer-desktop-icon-in-windows-xp-sp3/|title=Restore Missing or Disappeared IE (Internet Explorer) Desktop Icon in Windows XP SP3|date=May 11, 2008|work=Tip and Trick|accessdate=January 22, 2013}}</ref> * The ability to install [[service pack]]s cumulatively is no longer available in Service Pack 3 as it requires at least [[XP service pack 1|Service Pack 1]] to be installed first ([[XP Service Pack 2|Service Pack 2]] in the cases of the original [[Windows XP Media Center Edition]] and Windows XP Media Center Edition 2003).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc507836.aspx|title=Installing Windows XP Service Pack 3 (SP3)|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|work=[[Microsoft TechNet|TechNet]]|accessdate=November 7, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/949388 |title=Windows XP Service Pack 3 installation fails with an error message, and the following error is logged in the service pack installation log: "8007F0F4 - STATUS_PREREQUISITE_FAILED" |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=June 12, 2012 |work=Support |accessdate=November 7, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120618022213/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/949388 |archivedate=June 18, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Cumulative [[Slipstream (computing)|slipstreaming]], however, is still possible and supported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/950722 |title=After you create Windows XP Service Pack 3 slipstreamed media, your product key is not accepted |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=January 18, 2010 |work=Support |accessdate=January 22, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100127064648/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/950722 |archivedate=January 27, 2010 |df= }}</ref> * The [[Energy Star]] [[logo]] in the ''Display Properties'' dialog was removed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/946480 |title=List of fixes that are included in Windows XP Service Pack 3 |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=September 23, 2011 |work=Support |accessdate=November 7, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111023120247/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/946480 |archivedate=October 23, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
===Media Center Edition 2005=== * Despite [[Windows XP Media Center Edition|this edition]] being developed from [[Windows XP Professional]], [[Windows domain|domain]] support is unavailable. [[Microsoft]] states that this is due to [[Windows Media Center Extender]]s requiring [[fast user switching]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/kb/887212 |title=You cannot join your computer to a domain in Windows XP Media Center Edition 2005 |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |date=November 19, 2004 |work=Support |accessdate=November 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051101091747/http://support.microsoft.com/kb/887212 |archivedate=November 1, 2005 |df= }}</ref> The exceptions to this are if it is selected during [[Installation (computer programs)|installation]] or already in use before an [[upgrade]], but leaving the domain will still disable the feature. * [[Windows Media Player]] 6.4 is no longer included.
==See also== * [[Features new to Windows XP]] * [[Windows Server 2003]] * [[List of features removed in Windows Vista]] * [[List of features removed in Windows 7]] * [[List of features removed in Windows 8]] * [[Features new to Windows Vista]] * [[Features new to Windows 7]] * [[Features new to Windows 8]] * [[Features new to Windows 10]]
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
[[Category:Windows XP]] [[Category:Software features|Windows XP]] [[Category:Microsoft lists]]

600 million |align=right| {{coord|20|55|S|134|50|E|name=Amelia Creek}} |- |[[Boxhole crater|Boxhole]] |[[Northern Territory]] |0.17 |5,400 ± 1,500 |align=right| {{coord|22|37|S|135|12|E|name=Boxhole}} |- |[[Connolly Basin crater|Connolly Basin]] |[[Western Australia]] |9 |< 60 million |align=right| {{coord|23|32|S|124|45|E|name=Connolly Basin}} |- |[[Crawford crater|Crawford]] |[[South Australia]] |8.5 |> 35 million |align=right| {{coord|34|43|S|139|2|E|name=Crawford}} |- |[[Dalgaranga crater|Dalgaranga]] |[[Western Australia]] |0.02 |about 3000 |align=right| {{coord|27|38|S|117|17|E|name=Dalgaranga}} |- |[[Flaxman crater|Flaxman]] |[[South Australia]] |10 |> 35 million |align=right| {{coord|34|37|S|139|4|E|name=Flaxman}} |- |[[Foelsche crater|Foelsche]] |[[Northern Territory]] |6 |> 545 million |align=right| {{coord|16|40|S|136|47|E|name=Foelsche}} |- |[[Glikson crater|Glikson]] |[[Western Australia]] |19 |< 508 million |align=right| {{coord|23|59|S|121|34|E|name=Glikson}} |- |[[Goat Paddock crater|Goat Paddock]] |[[Western Australia]] |5 |< 50 million |align=right| {{coord|18|20|S|126|40|E|name=Goat Paddock}} |- |[[Gosses Bluff crater|Gosses Bluff]] |[[Northern Territory]] |22 |142.5 ± 0.8 million |align=right| {{coord|23|49|S|132|19|E|name=Gosses Bluff}} |- |[[Goyder crater|Goyder]] |[[Northern Territory]] |3 |< 1.4 billion |align=right| {{coord|13|9|S|135|2|E|name=Goyder}} |- |[[Henbury crater|Henbury]] |[[Northern Territory]] |0.16 |4200 ± 1900 |align=right| {{coord|24|34|S|133|09|E|name=Henbury}} |- |[[Kelly West crater|Kelly West]] |[[Northern Territory]] |10 |> 550 million |align=right| {{coord|19|56|S|133|57|E|name=Kelly West}} |- |[[Lawn Hill crater|Lawn Hill]] |[[Queensland]] |18 |> 515 million |align=right| {{coord|18|40|S|138|39|E|name=Lawn Hill}} |- |[[Liverpool crater|Liverpool]] |[[Northern Territory]] |1.6 |1000 - 543 million |align=right| {{coord|12|24|S|134|3|E|name=Liverpool}} |- |[[Matt Wilson (crater)|Matt Wilson]] |[[Northern Territory]] |7.5 |< 1402 ± 440 million |align=right|{{coord|15|30|4|S|131|10|43|E|name=Wilson}} |- |[[Mount Toondina crater|Mount Toondina]] |[[South Australia]] |4 |< 110 million |align=right| {{coord|27|57|S|135|22|E|name=Mount Toondina}} |- |[[Piccaninny crater|Piccaninny]] |[[Western Australia]] |7 |< 360 million |align=right| {{coord|17|26|S|128|26|E|name=Piccaninny}} |- |[[Shoemaker crater|Shoemaker]]
(formerly Teague) |[[Western Australia]] |30 |Proterozoic |align=right| {{coord|25|52|S|120|53|E|name=Shoemaker}} |- |[[Spider crater|Spider]] |[[Western Australia]] |13 |> 570 million |align=right| {{coord|16|44|S|126|5|E|name=Spider}} |- |[[Strangways crater|Strangways]] |[[Northern Territory]] |25 |646 ± 42 million |align=right| {{coord|15|12|S|133|35|E|name=Strangways}} |- |[[Tookoonooka crater|Tookoonooka]] |[[Queensland]] |55 |128 ± 5 million |align=right| {{coord|27|7|S|142|50|E|name=Tookoonooka}} |- |[[Veevers crater|Veevers]] |[[Western Australia]] |0.08 |< 20 thousand |align=right| {{coord|22|58|S|125|22|E|name=Veevers}} |- |[[Wolfe Creek crater|Wolfe Creek]] |[[Western Australia]] |0.87 |300,000 |align=right| {{coord|19|10|S|127|48|E|name=Wolfe Creek}} |- |[[Woodleigh crater|Woodleigh]] |[[Western Australia]] |60–120 |364 ± 8 million |align=right| {{coord|26|3|S|114|40|E|name=Woodleigh}} |- |[[Yarrabubba crater|Yarrabubba]] |[[Western Australia]] |30 |about 2 billion |align=right| {{coord|27|10|S|118|50|E|name=Yarrabubba}} |} == Unconfirmed impact craters == {{main|List of unconfirmed impact craters on Earth}} The following craters are officially considered "unconfirmed" because they are not listed in the Earth Impact Database. Due to stringent requirements regarding evidence and peer-reviewed publication, newly discovered craters or those with difficulty collecting evidence generally are known for some time before becoming listed. However, entries on the unconfirmed list could still have an impact origin disproven. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Name !State !Diameter !Age !Coordinates |- |[[Bedout]] |[[Indian Ocean]], [[Western Australia]] |200 km |250 million |align=right| {{coord|18|S|119|E|name=Bedout}} |- |[[Darwin Crater]] |[[Tasmania]] |1.2 km |800 thousand |align=right| {{coord|42|19|S|145|40|E|name=Darwin crater}} |- |[[East Warburton Basin]] |[[South Australia]] |200 km[http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/world-s-largest-asteroid-impact-zone-found-in-australia-1.3006800 World's largest asteroid impact zone found in Australia: Meteorite broke in two, leaving two craters each 200 km across]. Mar 24, 2015 |about 300-360 million |align=right| {{coord|27|0|S|140|5|E|name=East Warburton Basin}} |- |[[West Warburton Basin]] |[[South Australia]] |200 km |about 300-360 million | |- |[[Massive Australian Precambrian/Cambrian Impact Structure,MAPCIS|Massive Australian Precambrian/Cambrian
Impact Structure (MAPCIS)]] |[[Northern Territory]] |multiple rings 500 km - 2000 km |545 million = P/C boundary |align=right| {{coord|25|33|S|131|23|E|name=MAPCIS}} |- |[[Hickman Crater]] |[[Newman, Western Australia]] |0.27 km |10 - 100 thousand |align=right| {{coord|23|2|13.4|S|119|40|59.3|E|name=Hickman Crater}} |- |Unnamed impact[http://www.unisaustralia.com/uq-researcher-discovers-giant-asteroid-impact/ UQ Researcher Discovers Giant Asteroid Impact] |[[Cooper Basin]], [[South Australia]] | 80 km - 160 km |300 million |align=right| (impact centre is unknown) |- |[[Winton crustal anomaly|Unnamed impact]]{{cite web|url=http://www.ga.gov.au/news-events/news/latest-news/potential-asteroid-impact-identified-in-western-queensland|title=Potential asteroid impact identified in western Queensland|publisher=Geoscience Australia|accessdate=26 June 2016}} |Upper [[Diamantina River]], [[Queensland]] |130 km |300 million |align=right| {{Coord|-22.15|141.9|name=?}} |- |} == See also == * [[Impact crater]]s * [[Impact event]]s * [[Bolide]]s and [[Meteorite]]s * [[Earth Impact Database]] – primary source * [[Traces of Catastrophe]] book from [[Lunar and Planetary Institute]] - comprehensive reference on impact crater science ==Notes== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1162 Unesco] * [https://www.unb.ca/passc/ImpactDatabase/ Earth Impact Database] – List of confirmed earth impact sites at the Planetary and Space Science Centre, [[University of New Brunswick]] * [http://impacts.rajmon.cz Impact Database] (formerly Suspected Earth Impact Sites list) maintained by David Rajmon for [https://web.archive.org/web/20140816123552/http://web.eps.utk.edu/~faculty/ifsg.htm Impact Field Studies Group], USA {{Impact cratering on Earth}} [[Category:Impact craters of Australia| ]] [[Category:Lists of impact craters on Earth|Australia]] [[Category:Lists of coordinates|Impact craters on Earth, List of]] [[Category:Australia geology-related lists|Impact craters]]

[[File:Cyproterone_acetate.svg|thumb|right|225px|[[Cyproterone acetate]], the most well-known and widely used steroidal antiandrogen.]] [[File:Trimethyl_steroid-nomenclature.svg|thumb|right|225px|[[Steroid]] ring system.]]
This is a '''list of [[steroidal antiandrogen]]s'''.
{{TOC limit|2}}
==Progesterone derivatives== * [[11α-Hydroxyprogesterone]] = 11α-hydroxyprogesterone * [[Chlormadinone acetate]] = 17α-acetoxy-6-chloro-δ<sup>6</sup>-progesterone * [[Clometerone]] (L-38000) = 6α-chloro-16α-methylprogesterone * [[Cyproterone]] (SH-80881) = 1,2α-methylene-6-chloro-δ<sup>6</sup>-17α-hydroxyprogesterone * [[Cyproterone acetate]] = 1,2α-methylene-6-chloro-δ<sup>6</sup>-17α-acetoxyprogesterone * [[Edogestrone]] (PH-218) = 17α-acetoxy-3,3-ethylenedioxy-6-methylpregn-5-en-20-one * [[Medrogestone]] = 6,17α-dimethyl-δ<sup>6</sup>-progesterone * [[Megestrol acetate]] = 17α-acetoxy-δ<sup>6</sup>-6-methylprogesterone * [[Nomegestrol acetate]] = 17α-acetoxy-δ<sup>6</sup>-6-methyl-19-norprogesterone * [[Osaterone acetate]] (TZP-4238) = 17α-acetoxy-6-chloro-2-oxa-δ<sup>6</sup>-progesterone
==Testosterone derivatives== * [[Abiraterone]] (CB-7598) = 17-(3-pyridinyl)androsta-5,16-dien-3β-ol * [[Abiraterone acetate]] = 17-(3-pyridinyl)androsta-5,16-dien-3β-ol acetate * [[Benorterone]] (SKF-7690, FC-612) = 17α-methyl-''B''-nortestosterone * [[BOMT]] (Ro 7-2340) = 6α-bromo-4-oxa-17α-methyl-4,5α-dihydrotestosterone * [[Delanterone]] (GBR-21162) = 17β-dehydroxy-1α-methyl-δ<sup>16</sup>-testosterone * [[Dienogest]] = 17α-cyanomethyl-19-nor-δ<sup>9(10)</sup>-testosterone * [[Epitestosterone]] = 17α-epitestosterone * [[Galeterone]] (TOK-001, VN/124-1) = 17-(1H-benzimidazol-1-yl)androsta-5,16-dien-3β-ol * [[Metogest]] (SC-14207) = 16,16-dimethyl-19-nortestosterone * [[Mifepristone]] = 11β-[p-(dimethylamino)phenyl]-17-(1-propynyl)-δ<sup>9</sup>-19-nortestosterone * [[Oxendolone]] (TSAA-291) = 16β-ethyl-19-nortestosterone * [[Rosterolone]] (SH-434, 17α-propylmesterolone) = 1α-methyl-17α-propyl-4,5α-dihydrotestosterone * [[Topterone]] (WIN-17665) = 17α-propyltestosterone * [[Trimethyltrienolone]] (R-2956, RU-2956) = 2α,2β,17α-trimethyl-19-nor-δ<sup>9,11</sup>-testosterone * [[Zanoterone]] (WIN-49596) = (5α,17α)-1'-(methylsulfonyl)-1'-H-pregn-20-yno[3,2-c]pyrazol-17-ol
==Spirolactone derivatives== {{Main|Spirolactone}}
* [[SC-5233]] (spirolactone) = 17α-(2-carboxyethyl)testosterone γ-lactone * [[SC-8109]] = 19-norspirolactone * [[Canrenone]] (aldadiene) = Δ<sup>6</sup>-spirolactone * [[Dicirenone]] (SC-26304) = 7α-carboxyisopropylspirolactone * [[Drospirenone]] = 6β,7β:15β,16β-dimethylenespirolactone * [[Mespirenone]] (ZK-94679) = Δ<sup>1</sup>-7α-acetylthio-15β,16β-methylenespirolactone * [[Mexrenone]] (ZK-32055, SC-25152) = 7α-(methoxycarbonyl)spirolactone * [[Prorenone]] (SC-23133) = 6α,7α-methylenespirolactone * [[Spironolactone]] = 7α-acetylthiospirolactone * [[Spirorenone]] (ZK-35973) = Δ<sup>1</sup>-6β,7β:15β,16β-dimethylenespirolactone * [[Spiroxasone]] = 7α-acetylthiospirolactone with the ketone group removed from the C17α spirolactone ring
==Cortisol derivatives== * [[9,11-Dehydrocortexolone 17α-butyrate]] (CB-03-04) = 17α-(butyryloxy)-9,11-didehydrodeoxycorticosterone * [[Clascoterone]] (CB-03-01; cortexolone 17α-propionate, 11-deoxycortisol 17α-propionate) = 17α-(propionyloxy)deoxycorticosterone
==Others== * [[Guggulsterone]] = pregna-4,17-diene-3,16-dione * [[Nordinone]] = 11α-hydroxy-17,17-dimethyl-18-norandrosta-4,13-dien-3-one

page.title: Master of Science in Organizational Leadership

revision.text:
The '''Master of Science in Organizational Leadership''' (MSOL) is a multidisciplinary [[master's degree]] in [[leadership studies]].
It is an alternative to, not a substitute for, the traditional [[Master of Business Administration]] (MBA) degree. The MSOL degree is multidisciplinary and focuses more on people and [[organizational design|organization issues]], and relatively less on business topics such as finance, accounting and marketing. (For example, the MSOL will offer courses in psychology and philosophy as well as courses in business and management.) Also, The MSOL degree is intended for those who are already established in a career, while, in contrast, those who are preparing to enter the world of work or change careers often seek an MBA degree.
The MSOL degree is similar to the [[Master of Science in Leadership]] (MSL) degree and the Masters of Organizational Leadership (MAOL).
[[Category:Leadership studies]] [[Category:Business qualifications]] [[Category:Master's degrees]]
